children.name: house
children.definition: a building for people to live in, that may have more than one level, and may either stand separately or be joined to other buildings:nhà
examples: a four-bedroom house
in a house
every room in the house
at sb’s house
We met at Alison’s house.
Why don’t you all come over to our house for coffee?
a detached houseUK a house that is not joined to another house : nhà tách biệt
a detached house in Surrey/a detached four-bedroomed house
a semi-detached houseUK a house that is joined to another house on one side : nhà bán tách biệt
a three-bedroom semi-detached house
a terraced houseUK /row houseUS a house that is in a row of houses that are all joined together : nhà liên kế
The street ran between rows of dingy terraced houses.
country house[C]British Englisha large house in the countryside, especially one that is of historical interest : trang viên, nhà quê
The hotel was originally an Edwardian country house.
ranch house[C] a house that usually has only one level, and a roof that does not slope much, either in a city or on a ranch : nhà trệt

children.name: live in a house
examples: They live in a really big house in Hampstead.

children.name: buy a house
examples: We bought this house when Liam was just a baby.

children.name: rent a house
examples: While he was working in London, Ken rented a house in Fulham.

children.name: sell a house
examples: We decided to sell the house and move back to Seattle.

children.name: put your house on the market
children.definition: make it available for people to buy
examples: They put the house on the market and began looking for an apartment.

children.name: move into/out of a house
examples: We’re moving into our new house next week.

children.name: build a house
examples: They’re building a house on land overlooking Galway Bay.

children.name: put up a house
children.definition: build a house, especially when it seems very quick
examples: I think they’ve ruined the village by putting up these new houses.

children.name: renovate a house
children.definition: repair a house so that it is in good condition again
examples: He makes money by renovating old houses and selling them on.

children.name: decorate a house
children.definition: put paint or wallpaper on the inside walls of a house
examples: If we’re going to decorate the house, let’s get professionals in.

children.name: do up a houseinformal
children.definition: decorate it
examples: We’ve been doing up the house bit by bit since we first moved in.

children.name: a private house
children.definition: one owned by someone
examples: It was a residential neighborhood of private houses.

children.name: a rented house
children.definition: one owned by someone who rents it to people
examples: She shares a rented house with three other students.

children.name: a council houseUK
children.definition: one owned by a local council that people can rent cheaply
examples: The rent rise is a blow to council house tenants.

children.name: a Georgian/Victorian/Edwardian etc house
children.definition: a house in Britain that was built during the reign of a particular king or queen
examples: They live in a lovely old Edwardian house with high ceilings.

children.name: house prices
examples: House prices have tripled over the last ten years.

children.name: a house owner
examples: All house owners must pay council tax.

children.name: a house purchase
examples: A solicitor can help you with the legal aspects of a house purchase.

children.name: house hunting
children.definition: the activity of looking at houses that you might buy
examples: Have you had any success with your house hunting?

children.name: bungalow
children.definition: a small house in which all the rooms are on the same level:nhà một tầng
examples: He and his wife lived in a modern bungalow on the outskirts of the city.
Bungalows are suitable for many elderly people.

children.name: townhouse
children.definition: 1InUSa house in a group of houses that share one or more walls
examples: Old buildings were knocked down, and new apartments and townhouses built.

children.name: 2In UK,townhouseis often used about a large and impressive house in a fashionable area of a city :nhà phố
examples: an 18th-century townhouse in Bath.

children.name: mansion
children.definition: a very large and impressive house:biệt thự
examples: a magnificent mansion set in 2000 acres of countryside
an eleven-bedroom mansion in Hancock Park
The street is lined with enormous mansions where the rich and famous live.
the family’s Beverly Hills mansion

children.name: duplex
children.definition: USa type of house that is divided into two parts, so that it has two separate homes in it : nhà hai căn hộ
examples: Four miles from the city centre, Heath Square comprises 72 apartments, duplexes and showhouses.
Both apartments and duplexes have a generous electrical specification.

children.name: apartment
children.definition: especially USa set of roomsthat are usually all on thesame leveland are part of a larger building:căn hộ
examples: She lives in a small apartment.

children.name: a one-bedroom/two-bedroom etc apartment
children.definition: alsoone-bedroomed/two-bedroomed apartmentBritish English
examples: A tiny one-bedroom apartment was all she could afford.

children.name: a studio apartment
children.definition: with just one main room, which you use for sleeping, cooking, and eating
examples: Studio apartments can be a good option for those who want a cheap place in a good location.

children.name: a first-floor/second-floor etc apartment
examples: We had a fourth-floor apartment, and it was difficult going up and down all those stairs.

children.name: a basement apartment
children.definition: below the level of the ground
examples: a dark basement apartment

children.name: a penthouse apartment
children.definition: on the top floor of a building
examples: She bought a penthouse apartment in Santa Monica.

children.name: a luxury apartment
examples: The school has been converted into luxury apartments.

children.name: a furnished/unfurnished apartment
children.definition: with or without furniture
examples: a luxurious two-bedroomed unfurnished apartment situated in the heart of town

children.name: a holiday apartment
examples: British English,a vacation apartmentAmerican English We rented a holiday apartment on Mallorca.

children.name: live in an apartment
examples: He lived in a small apartment on the third floor.

children.name: buy/rent an apartment
examples: Tom rented an apartment at the top of the building.

children.name: share an apartment
examples: I’m sharing the apartment with a group of friends.

children.name: own an apartment
examples: My parents own an apartment in Madrid.

children.name: move into/out of an apartment
children.definition: start living in a new apartment, or leave an apartment in order to live somewhere else
examples: They moved into the apartment last Easter.

children.name: an apartment building
children.definition: alsoan apartment blockBritish English,apartment houseAmerican English
examples: a five-storey apartment block|Our apartment building is the last block on the right, opposite the bank.

children.name: an apartment complex
children.definition: a group of buildings containing apartments

children.name: high-rise apartment buildinga tall apartment building with many levels
examples: High-rise apartment buildings have gone up where once there was open land.

children.name: flat
children.definition: UKa place for people to live that consists of a set of rooms that are part of a larger building. In British English, people usually sayflat.Apartmentis used about large and expensive flats, or in advertisements : căn hộ
examples: They have a flat in Crouch End.

children.name: small
examples: The flat was too small for the three of them.

children.name: big/spacious
examples: It was a big flat with eight or nine rooms.

children.name: cramped/poky
children.definition: too small and not comfortable
examples: She spends most days shut up in a poky flat looking after her disabled Mum.

children.name: a one-bedroom/two-bedroom etc flat
examples: She lived in a one-bedroom flat in Clapham.

children.name: a one-room/two-room etc flat
examples: Their home is a humble two-room flat.

children.name: a ground-floor/first-floor/second-floor etc flat
examples: We’re moving into a first-floor flat.

children.name: a basement flat
children.definition: a flat that is below ground level
examples: They lived in a basement flat in South London.

children.name: a studio flat
children.definition: with one main room
examples: I might just be able to afford a tiny studio flat.

children.name: high-rise flats
children.definition: flats in a very tall building
examples: Many high-rise flats were built in the 1970s.

children.name: a rented flat
examples: He returned to his rented flat in Cheltenham.

children.name: a luxury flat
examples: Laura shares a luxury flat with her sister Chloe.

children.name: a self-contained flat
children.definition: a flat with its own kitchen and bathroom
examples: We rented a self-contained flat in the city centre.

children.name: a furnished/unfurnished flat
children.definition: a rented flat that does or does not have furniture
examples: She found a job and a furnished flat.

children.name: a holiday flat
examples: The building has been converted into three holiday flats.

children.name: a block of flats
children.definition: a large building divided into separate flats
examples: At the time, I lived in a block of flats in St John’s Wood.

children.name: live in a flat
examples: Terry lived in a flat on the second floor.

children.name: buy a flat
examples: I had planned to buy a flat with Geraldine.

children.name: rent a flat
examples: Renting a flat can be very expensive in this part of town.

children.name: move into a flat
examples: They move into their new flat next week.

children.name: own a flat
examples: The couple own their own flat in Peebles.

children.name: condominium
children.definition: /condoinformal  US an apartment in a building that consists of several apartments, all of which are owned by the people who live in them:chế độ quản lý chung
examples: He lives in a condo in San Jose.
They rent out their condominium to skiers during the winter.

children.name: housing
children.definition: the houses, flats etc within a particular area that are available for or are provided for people to live in:nhà cửa,nơi ăn chốn ở
examples: health problems caused by bad housing
a scheme to provide affordable housing for local people
Most of the housing in the area is sub-standard and nothing is being done to improve it.
The council is making a great effort to provide cheap housing and more public facilities.
There's a shortage of cheap housing in the region.
housing association[ C + sing/pl verb ] UK a group of people who join together so that they can build or buy houses or apartments at low costhội phát triển nhà ở

children.name: shack
children.definition: a small building that has not been built very well : lán, lều (sơ sài)
examples: a tin shack

children.name: cottage
children.definition: a small house, especially an old house in the country - use this especially about houses in the UK: nhà tranh
examples: She lives in a charming cottage deep in the Kent countryside.

children.name: little/small/tiny
examples: He lived all his life in a small cottage by the river.

children.name: remote
children.definition: far from any towns
examples: There’s a remote cottage in the mountains where we go for walking holidays.

children.name: picturesque
children.definition: pretty
examples: Would you prefer to live in a modern house or a picturesque cottage?

children.name: a thatched cottage
children.definition: with a roof made from dry straw
examples: a row of small thatched cottages

children.name: a country cottage
children.definition: in the countryside
examples: A lot of people dream of living in a country cottage.

children.name: a stone cottage
examples: The village is full of old stone cottages with thatched roofs.

children.name: a holiday cottageBritish English
children.definition: that people use or rent for holidays
examples: We rented a holiday cottage in Wales.

children.name: a weekend/summer cottage
children.definition: that the owners go to at weekends or in the summer
examples: They live in London but they also have a weekend cottage by the sea.

children.name: hut
children.definition: a small simple building with only one or two rooms: túp lều
examples: a wooden hut
a mountain hut
a row of beach huts

children.name: cabin
children.definition: a small house, especially one built of wood in an area of forest or mountains : nhà gỗ nhỏ, chòi gỗ

children.name: a log cabin
examples: I have a log cabin in Canada.

children.name: mobile home
children.definition: a type of house that can be pulled by a large vehicle and moved to another place : nhà di động
examples: The mother's plan includes living in a mobile home in a trailer park with this man.

children.name: detached
children.definition: especially UKa detached house or garage is not joined to another building : tách rời

children.name: semi-detached
children.definition: UK a semi-detached house is joined to another house on one side

children.name: apartment building
children.definition: / apartment blockUK/apartment houseUS/ block of flatsUK  a large building that is divided into apartments: chung cư
examples: My house was the only apartment building in that block, and we lived on the sixth floor.

children.name: tenement
children.definition: a large building divided into apartments, especially in the poorer areas of a city :chung cư
examples: You do not specify which floor your property is on within the tenement.

children.name: tenement building/house/block
examples: He spent his working life designing commercial premises, tenements and mansion houses.
The flat was on the first floor of a tenement block, and had a lovely front room.

children.name: villa
children.definition: a house usually in the countryside or near the sea, especially in southernEurope, and often one which people can rent for a holiday :biệt thự
examples: They have a villa inSpain.

children.name: hostel
children.definition: an establishment which provides inexpensive food and lodging for a specific group of people, such as students, workers, or travellers: ký túc xá

children.name: a student hostel
examples: If you're traveling solo, a hostel can be cheaper than a hotel.

children.name: institution
children.definition: mainly disapproving a place or building where people are sent to be cared for, especially a hospital or prison : cơ quan
examples: about 5 per cent of elderly people live in institutions
